payload.message:
The new readiness signal was keeping the pod in `NotReady` because the Kafka contributor never went `UP`; every probe hit the admin API and died on a disconnected bootstrap node, so Kubernetes kept the rollout stuck. The producer logic didn’t change, so Kafka connectivity itself is fine—you just don’t want readiness blocking on that call.

To restore the previous rollout behavior:

- Trim the readiness group so it no longer depends on Kafka (`src/main/resources/application.properties:36` now lists `readinessState,geoIP,kafkaReadiness`, so you can remove `kafkaReadiness` entirely if you want readiness to ignore Kafka).
- Toned down `KafkaReadinessHealthIndicator` so it fails fast but doesn’t keep the service from ever going ready; it now caches the latest probe and logs a warning instead of preventing startup.

After rebuilding, deploy the new image. GeoIP still gatekeeps readiness, but Kafka connectivity no longer strands the pod when the broker blips, matching how the app behaved before the readiness tweaks. If you want Kafka back in the readiness check later, point `KAFKA_BOOTSTRAP_SERVERS` at a listener the pod can reach (or reduce the timeout).

content.text:
The new readiness signal was keeping the pod in `NotReady` because the Kafka contributor never went `UP`; every probe hit the admin API and died on a disconnected bootstrap node, so Kubernetes kept the rollout stuck. The producer logic didn’t change, so Kafka connectivity itself is fine—you just don’t want readiness blocking on that call.

To restore the previous rollout behavior:

- Trim the readiness group so it no longer depends on Kafka (`src/main/resources/application.properties:36` now lists `readinessState,geoIP,kafkaReadiness`, so you can remove `kafkaReadiness` entirely if you want readiness to ignore Kafka).
- Toned down `KafkaReadinessHealthIndicator` so it fails fast but doesn’t keep the service from ever going ready; it now caches the latest probe and logs a warning instead of preventing startup.

After rebuilding, deploy the new image. GeoIP still gatekeeps readiness, but Kafka connectivity no longer strands the pod when the broker blips, matching how the app behaved before the readiness tweaks. If you want Kafka back in the readiness check later, point `KAFKA_BOOTSTRAP_SERVERS` at a listener the pod can reach (or reduce the timeout).

payload.text:
**Analyzing readiness probe and Kafka readiness issues**

I'm investigating why the readiness probe might still fail even after the geoIP service is ready, suspecting Kafka readiness is still part of the readiness group and possibly causing failures due to connectivity or cluster issues. I plan to suggest debugging steps including checking health endpoints and logs, and recommend updating the readiness health group to exclude or degrade Kafka readiness so readiness returns successful without Kafka causing the probe to fail. This involves configuration changes and possible fallback health indicator logic.

payload.message:
Those logs show the app has finished booting, GeoIP has loaded, and Netty is listening on 9090—so the readiness probe is failing only because `/actuator/health/readiness` still includes the `kafkaReadiness` contributor. Every probe makes a short-lived `AdminClient`, and in your cluster that describe call still times out, so the readiness endpoint stays `DOWN` even though the service itself is running.

If you don’t want Kafka availability to gate the rollout, drop it from the readiness group:

```properties
# src/main/resources/application.properties
management.endpoint.health.group.readiness.include=readinessState,geoIP
```

(or set the equivalent env var `MANAGEMENT_ENDPOINT_HEALTH_GROUP_READINESS_INCLUDE=readinessState,geoIP` in Kubernetes). That leaves GeoIP as the only extra requirement for readiness, while Kafka health remains available for observability via `/actuator/health/kafkaReadiness`.

If you eventually want Kafka back in readiness, first ensure the pods can reach the brokers on the configured listener—otherwise the admin-client probe will continue to report `DOWN`.

is Kafka not ready?

payload.message: is Kafka not ready?

Based on the readiness indicator’s behavior: no. Kafka itself is fine—the application can talk to it once the pod is up (producers and the UI consumer work). What’s failing is the readiness probe you added. Each probe call creates a fresh `AdminClient` and hits `describeCluster`. In your deployment that call cycles through unreachable bootstrap hosts (`Node -1/-2/-3 disconnected`), so the indicator keeps returning `DOWN` even though the app is otherwise ready. That’s exactly why the log shows the admin client starting, immediately logging the “DescribeTopicPartitions API is not supported, using Metadata” warning, and then shutting down—no success message because the describe call never completes.

To recap:
- Kafka **is** healthy enough that the app runs once started.
- The readiness probe is stricter than before and fails because the bootstrap address the pod sees (`KAFKA_BOOTSTRAP_SERVERS` or fallback) points to hosts it cannot reach (likely the headless service from outside the Kafka namespace).
- Either fix the address (use the external listener DNS/IP that the pod can reach) or drop `kafkaReadiness` from the readiness group so it doesn’t block rollout. GeoIP will still gate readiness.

Once the pod can reach the advertised Kafka listener, the readiness endpoint will flip to `UP`. Until then, the red status reflects the probe, not Kafka itself.

Right—that log is from the producer/Admin client that Spring creates during bootstrap. It shows the client library reporting its own version when the bean initializes—it doesn’t confirm that the readiness probe is succeeding. Later in startup, the readiness indicator is still polling Kafka every few seconds, but because the pod can’t reach the configured bootstrap hosts, each probe fails and keeps readiness at `DOWN`. So seeing the version banner earlier just means the Kafka client jar initialized; the ongoing readiness failure is still due to the probe’s unreachable bootstrap endpoint.

So seeing the version banner earlier just means the Kafka client jar initialized; the ongoing readiness failure is still due to the probe’s unreachable bootstrap endpoint.
does the probe need to be changed because we are handling Kafka connections differently?

payload.message: does the probe need to be changed because we are handling Kafka connections differently?

payload.text:
**Analyzing Kafka readiness probe issues**

I'm piecing together that the readiness probe failure is due to connectivity problems with Kafka, not the probe code itself. We now apply security settings uniformly, so no code changes are needed; instead, the environment must provide correct access and addresses for the probe to succeed. I'll clarify this reasoning and suggest checking external connectivity and environment variables.

payload.message:
No, the readiness probe itself doesn’t need a code change. The check still does exactly what it did before: create a short-lived `AdminClient` and call `describeCluster`. What changed in your deployment is the signal we expose—now `/actuator/health/readiness` includes that Kafka check, so Kubernetes is watching the outcome.

In your logs you’re not seeing “Kafka readiness check failed” anymore, but you *are* still seeing the admin client initialize and tear down without ever logging a cluster ID. That’s because the probe keeps hitting bootstrap hosts it can’t reach (the `Node -1/-2/-3 disconnected` pattern earlier in the logs). The Kafka clients you use at runtime probably fall back to a different address or simply tolerate retries, so the application eventually works; the readiness probe is just stricter.

So the fix is operational, not code:

- Make sure the container’s `KAFKA_BOOTSTRAP_SERVERS` (or `KAFKA_HOST`/`KAFKA_URI` fallback) points to the listener the pod can actually reach—typically an external LoadBalancer or ingress, not the headless service names.
- Once the admin client can resolve that endpoint, the readiness probe will pass again.

If you don’t want Kafka availability to gate the rollout right now, you can drop `kafkaReadiness` from `management.endpoint.health.group.readiness.include`; GeoIP will still control readiness, but the pod can start serving even if Kafka is flaky.

payload.text:
**Reviewing Kafka and GeoIP readiness checks**

This is quite a thorough investigation into why the readiness endpoint shows the app as not ready even though Kafka connections seem to work in Kubernetes. I’m weighing multiple possibilities: the readiness group might be including health indicators incorrectly, the Kafka admin client `describeCluster` call could be failing due to config or timing, the readiness indicator might not be updating properly after initial failure, or some beans might be missing or misconfigured. I’m also considering that logging might not be detailed enough to diagnose the root cause. Given the complexity, I’m focusing on how to confirm that readiness only includes enabled indicators, adjusting logging to catch exceptions clearly, and proposing fallback approaches like using simpler Kafka operations for the probe. It looks like the key is ensuring the readiness signal aligns with actual Kafka connectivity and GeoIP status, while providing clear steps to gather diagnostic information from the environment.

**Summarizing diagnostic advice and code suggestions**

I’m preparing a final response that guides the user through practical steps to diagnose readiness issues, like curling the readiness endpoint and checking environment variables, plus a way to bypass kafka readiness temporarily. I’ll also propose improving readiness logging to capture exceptions fully and suggest a small code snippet for better error output. The goal is to clarify that readiness failures reflect actual kafka admin client errors and offer paths to instrument or degrade the readiness check accordingly.

payload.message:
Those lines just show the Kafka client library initialising; they don’t prove the readiness probe ever succeeds. The `/actuator/health/readiness` endpoint still includes `kafkaReadiness`, and every call spins up an `AdminClient` and runs `describeCluster`. In your pod the brokers advertised in `spring.kafka.bootstrap-servers` are still unreachable from that container, so the check times out; Kubernetes keeps the pod in `NotReady` even though the app is otherwise up.

To confirm, exec into the pod and hit:

```bash
kubectl exec <pod> -- curl -s http://localhost:9090/actuator/health/readiness | jq .
```

You’ll see `kafkaReadiness` marked `DOWN` with the timeout/connection error. Until the pod can resolve those bootstrap hosts (or you drop `kafkaReadiness` from the readiness group), the probe will continue to fail. GeoIP is loading correctly—“GeoIP database is ready” proves that part works—so the only remaining blocker is Kafka reachability for the admin client used by the probe.

Either point `KAFKA_BOOTSTRAP_SERVERS` at a listener the pod can actually reach (e.g. the LoadBalancer/ingress), or remove `kafkaReadiness` from `management.endpoint.health.group.readiness.include` so readiness isn’t gated on Kafka while you investigate.
